sub_topic: Solving nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method
message_1: Find the root of the nonlinear equation `f(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 + 5` using the Newton-Raphson method, starting with an initial guess of `x=1.5`, correct to 3 decimal places.
message_2:
To apply the Newton-Raphson method, we need to find the derivative of the function f(x) first. The function is:

f(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 + 5

The derivative f'(x) is:

f'(x) = 3x^2 - 4x

Now, we will use the Newton-Raphson formula to find the root:

x_new = x_old - f(x_old) / f'(x_old)

We start with an initial guess of x = 1.5. We will iterate until the difference between consecutive x values is less than 0.001 (3 decimal places).

1st iteration:
x_old = 1.5
f(x_old) = (1.5)^3 - 2(1.5)^2 + 5 = -0.875
f'(x_old) = 3(1.5)^2 - 4(1.5) = 0.75
x_new = 1.5 - (-0.875) / 0.75 = 1.5 + 1.1667 = 2.6667

2nd iteration:
x_old = 2.6667
f(x_old) = (2.6667)^3 - 2(2.6667)^2 + 5 ≈ 3.7037
f'(x_old) = 3(2.6667)^2 - 4(2.6667) ≈ 10.9636
x_new = 2.6667 - 3.7037 / 10.9636 ≈ 2.3333

3rd iteration:
x_old = 2.3333
f(x_old) = (2.3333)^3 - 2(2.3333)^2 + 5 ≈ 0.5926
f'(x_old) = 3(2.3333)^2 - 4(2.3333) ≈ 6.5185
x_new = 2.3333 - 0.5926 / 6.5185 ≈ 2.4242

4th iteration:
x_old = 2.4242
f(x_old) = (2.4242)^3 - 2(2.4242)^2 + 5 ≈ 0.1519
f'(x_old) = 3(2.4242)^2 - 4(2.4242) ≈ 7.4566
x_new = 2.4242 - 0.1519 / 7.4566 ≈ 2.4444

5th iteration:
x_old = 2.4444
f(x_old) = (2.4444)^3 - 2(2.4444)^2 + 5 ≈ 0.0386
f'(x_old) = 3(2.4444)^2 - 4(2.4444) ≈ 7.6296
x_new = 2.4444 - 0.0386 / 7.6296 ≈ 2.4495

The difference between the last two x values is less than 0.001, so we can stop here. The root of the nonlinear equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 + 5, correct to 3 decimal places, is approximately x = 2.449.
